abstract.p: Three workers' advocacy groups, Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund, Chinese Staff and Workers' Assn and National Mobilization Against Sweatshops, announce that Street Beat Sportswear, women's clothing manufacturer, has agreed to pay them $85,000 in legal fees and damages after judge ruled that company had filed improper, retaliatory lawsuit against three organizations (S)

block.p: Three workers' advocacy groups announced yesterday that Street Beat Sportswear, a women's clothing manufacturer, agreed this week to pay them $85,000 in legal fees and damages. That settlement came after a judge ruled that the company had filed an improper, retaliatory lawsuit against the three organizations.

Under the settlement, Street Beat will pay $85,000 to three New York-based groups: the Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund, the Chinese Staff and Workers' Association and the National Mobilization Against Sweatshops.

Three workers' advocacy groups announced yesterday that Street Beat Sportswear, a women's clothing manufacturer, agreed this week to pay them $85,000 in legal fees and damages. That settlement came after a judge ruled that the company had filed an improper, retaliatory lawsuit against the three organizations.

Under the settlement, Street Beat will pay $85,000 to three New York-based groups: the Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund, the Chinese Staff and Workers' Association and the National Mobilization Against Sweatshops.

Last year, Justice Sheila Abdus-Salaam of New York State Supreme Court found that Street Beat broke a new law against frivolous and retaliatory lawsuits when it filed a lawsuit demanding $75 million in damages from the three advocacy groups. Street Beat filed that lawsuit after the Asian-American legal fund brought a lawsuit on behalf of 15 Chinese immigrant garment workers, charging the company with large-scale violations of minimum wage and overtime laws. In June 1999, Street Beat settled that suit by agreeing to pay $285,000.
